item.title: Framework new
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

[quote=“xEnt, post:17, topic:340822”]guys im working on a string framework my self

/**
* What this does is makes it easy for you to create strings
*
**/
class EasyString {
public String hardStr = null;

public static EasyString createString(String str) {
 EasyString ezstr = new EasyString();
 ezstr.hardStr = str;
 return ezstr;
}

public String getString() {
 return hardStr;
} 

}

example:

System.out.println(EasyString.createString(“hello world!”).getString());

whoever wants to use my code please leave credits on the project

credits:

98% me (xEnt)
1% google
1% java[/quote]
Woah, I was looking for that, thanks!

Read full topic

item.title: Framework new
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote="(Pro)grammer232, post:3, topic:340822"][quote author=Evil_ link=topic=437207.msg3212775#msg3212775 date=1274406230]
Instead of just being a dick, and saying what most people would and just harass you for being bad, I’ll try to teach you a little, and comment and what you did, and didn’t do:

You need to use proper indention, it makes it easier to read and not quite a hassle.
I don’t see how this is a framework, maybe I’m just overlooking it? =/

Don’t hardcode the location of Javac in your batch file (actually, you could use ant, it’s nice)

(I’m assuming you’re a moparscaper, so:)
At least you know how to use pacakages.
At least you know how to use a thread (well, you know how to start one…)

It’s nice to see you’re using try-catch, but try looking into also adding in finally. p.s. you don’t want to try-catch more than you need to.

Here’s an example of try-catch-finally:

Socket s = ...;
OutputStream os = null;

try {
    os = s.getOutputStream();

    // Use the output stream to your hearts content
} catch(IOException e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
} finally {
    if(os != null) {
        try {
            os.close();
        } catch(IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}

The point of using finally in that scenario is, what if you make the OutputStream, and you get an exception before you get to close it? Then the program jumps down to handling the exception and continues on without closing it. The finally block ALWAYS gets executed, whether you catch an exception or not, so it’s good to use for cleaning up.

If you really are looking into making a framework, be sure to document all your functions and fields, so that way the person using your framework will be able to see what everything does. Here’s a few links to stuff to look into:[

The Sun Java Tutorials
Documenting your applications
Concurrency Tutorial
[/quote]

thanks! i’ll try and get a new code up soon[/quote]
please dont

Read full topic
